The VendorId property can only be set during construction. It cannot be changed once an instance has been created.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.HidDeviceManager.ProductId

remarks.para: If PiProductId is set to a non-empty list, only devices with a Product ID that matches one of the items in the list will be managed. If the list is empty, all devices with any Product ID will be managed.
The PiProductId property can only be set during construction. It cannot be changed once an instance has been created.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.HidDeviceManager.EnumerateHidDevices
member.summary: Updates the list of devices to the set of currently connected devices that match the VendorID and ProductID properties.
member.remarks: This method is called automatically during construction and is not normally called again. It sets the list of managed devices to be those devices that are currently connected and match the VendorID and ProductID. If you call this method after construction, you will discard any memory of devices which were previously connected by have been disconnected by the user.

member.remarks: Some products use this for the product serial number.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.HidDeviceProperties.DeviceInterfacePath
member.summary: Gets or sets the HID device interface path.

remarks.para: This path uniquely identifies the device on the current system. It is the path obtained from SetupDiGetDeviceInterfaceDetail. It can be passed to CreateFile to open the device.
The GUID {4d1e55b2-f16f-11cf-88cb-001111000030} is the device interface class GUID defined for HID collections, know as GUID_DEVINTERFACE_HID.

The portion between the PID and the GUID uniquely identifies the device on the current system. It is an opaque value defined by windows. It changes if you plug the device into a different USB port. It can change on reboot.

Unfortunately windows returns this identifier sometimes with different case ( upper case vs lower case). For example, the identifier might be returned as
"\\?\HID#VID_0461&PID_0020#...",
and sometimes with lower case "vid_
"\\?\hid#vid_0461&pid_0020#...".
You should do case-insensitive comparisons.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.UsbDevice.Open(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32})
member.summary: Opens the devices with the specified serial numbers.

remarks.para: After opening the device, this method will check to see if the devices are currently attached to the computer. If all devices are attached they will be connected, and the Connected event will be raised, and this method returns true.

If one or more devices are not attached, this method returns false. This is not an error. When the devices are later attached, the system will automatically connect the devices and raise the Connected event.
If this instance has devices open, calling this method will close the open devices. If a specified serial number is the same as a device currently open, the device will be re-opened.

member.param: A list of serial numbers of the devices open.
member.returns: True if the device is connected.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.UsbDevice.Open(System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens the device with the specified serial number.

remarks.para: After opening the device, this method will check to see if the device is currently attached to the computer. If so, the device will be automatically connected, the Connected event will be raised, and this method returns true.
If the device is not attached, this method returns false. This is not an error. When the device is later attached, the system will automatically connect the device and raise the Connected event.
If this instance has a device open, calling this method will close the open device. If the specified serial number is the same as the device currently open, the device will be re-opened.

member.param: The serial number of the device to open.
member.returns: True if the device is connected.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.UsbDevice.Close
member.summary: Closes the device

remarks.para: Closing the device sets the serial number list to zero length. No device can be connected.
If the device is connected when the Close method is called, it will disconnect the device and raise the Disconnected event.

member.returns: True if a device was connected.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.UsbDevice.Connect
member.summary: Attempts to connect to the device
member.returns: True if the device is successfully connected.

remarks.para: You must lock the device before calling this method.
If this method succeeds and returns true, you should raise the Connected event.
If the device is already connected, will throw an exception.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.UsbDevice.Disconnect
member.summary: Disconnects from the device.
member.returns: True if the device was previously connected and is now disconnected.

remarks.para: You must lock the device before calling this method.
If this method succeeds and returns true, you should raise the Disconnected event.
If no device is currently connected, does nothing. This is not an error.

member.name: T:PiUsbNet.LabJack
member.summary: Provides an interface to a LabJack device.

remarks.para:
LabJack is a composite class. It uses a motor device to move a linear stage, but provides additional functionality:
You can convert motor steps to other units, typically mm.
You can compensate for the non-linear motion of a LabJack device using Linearization.
The multi-step Home procedure is handled automatically.

The LabJack device uses a scissor jack for motion. The motion of the pedestal is non-linear with respect to the motor motion. To compensate for this we apply a linearization algorithm that adjusts for the non- linear motion of the jack.
The property determines how the motor position (in motor steps) is converted to the height or property (in mm).
If is set to None, no linearization compensation is performed. In this case, the LabJack position is calculated using a simple scale factor -- the motor position times the MotorStepSize property.

If is set to LabJackLinearization, the and properties are used to calculate the position. This is the default value and should be used for Picard Industries UBS LabJack devices. The BHome and Offset properties are measured when each device is manufactured, and are supplied with each device. You must set the correct BHome and Offset properties for each device to correctly calculate the position. In addition the and properties affect the algorithm, and should be left at their default values unless otherwise instructed by Picard Industries.
values other than None or LabJackLinearization are reserved for future devices that may have a different linearization algorithm.

member.name: T:PiUsbNet.LabJack.LinearizationType
member.summary: The type of linearization to apply to the motor position.

member.name: F:PiUsbNet.LabJack.LinearizationType.None
member.summary: No linearization is applied. The LabJack position is the motor position converted to mm using the LabJack MotorStepSize.

member.name: F:PiUsbNet.LabJack.LinearizationType.LabJackLinearization
member.summary: LabJack linearization is used, using the LabJack BHome> and Offset properties.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.LabJack.Velocity
member.summary: Gets or sets the velocity.

remarks.para: The velocity is an integer between 1 and 12, where 1 is the slowest speed and 12 is the fastest speed.

We recommend that you limit your velocity to be 10 or less. These velocities should work well with most devices you connect to the LabJack. If your load is small and light, you may be able to use faster velocities (11 and 12). If you attempt to move too large a load at too high a speed, the motor may stall, or may miss steps and not move the full distance.
The following table shows the velocity settings and the approximate speed they correspond to.
The velocity is fixed for the duration of a move. If you change the velocity while the motor is moving, the change will apply to the next move.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.LabJack.Home
member.summary: Initiates the home procedure on the motor.

remarks.para: The LabJack uses a multi-step home procedure to ensure a reliable home position.
Call this method to initiate the home procedure. Homing is initiated and the method returns without waiting for homing to complete.
You can check whether the device has finished homing with the property or the GetStatus or GetStatusAll methods.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.LabJack.LoadSettingsFromRegistry(System.String)
member.summary: Loads properties from a registry key.

remarks.para: This method allows easy configuration of the object, and provides consistent operation across applications.
You must be connected to the device before calling this method. If you Disconnect and re-Connect to the device, you should call this method again.
The properties set by this method are:
The property is not affected by this method, since you must be connected to the device before loading the settings.

member.param: The registry keyName to be used. This is not the full path to the key, but is relative to HKCU\Software\Picard Industries. The standard keyName used by the USB 4D-Labjack software is USB 4D-LabJack\LegN, where N is 1, 2, or 3 (not 0 through 2).

member.name: T:PiUsbNet.Motor
member.summary: Provides an interface to a Motor device.

remarks.para: The USB Motor uses a stepper motor to rotate a shaft. The shaft is typically attached to a screw which moves a stage.
The motor position is specified in motor steps. The relation between motor steps and physical distance will depend on the pitch of the screw. There are 200 steps for each revolution of the shaft.
You can specify any position between 1 and 2^31-1 (+2147483647), but the physical upper limit depends on the device. See the method for a list of devices and their upper limits.

member.name: T:PiUsbNet.Motor.HomingState
member.summary: State of the homing operation

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.Motor.AllowMotionWithoutHome
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether MoveTo commands are allowed without homing the motor.
member.remarks: For most applications this value should be false. You can set this property true for testing, or if you have an application where the absolute position of the motor does not matter.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.Motor.HomeTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the timeout value for the homing operation.
member.remarks: If set to TimeSpan.Zero (the default value), no timeout will be applied. In this case the motor will search forever for the home switch.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.Motor.Home(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initiates the home search algorithm at a specified velocity

remarks.para: Call this method to initiate the home procedure. Homing is initiated and the method returns without waiting for homing to complete.

When homing is complete you will receive a event. You can also check whether the device has finished homing with the
property or the GetPositionAndStatus method.
Homing can fail if you have set a . After homing is complete you should check the property.

member.param: The to set before homing.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.Motor.Home
member.summary: Initiates the home search algorithm.

remarks.para: This method is similar to the method, except that it uses the most recently set velocity.
Call this method to initiate the home procedure. Homing is initiated and the method returns without waiting for homing to complete.

You can check whether the device has finished homing with the
property or the GetPositionAndStatus method.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.Motor.Velocity
member.summary: Gets or sets the velocity.

remarks.para: The velocity is an integer between 1 and 12, where 1 is the slowest speed and 12 is the fastest speed.

We recommend that you limit your velocity to be 10 or less. These velocities should work well with most devices you connect to the Motor. If your load is small and light, you may be able to use faster velocities (11 and 12). If you attempt to move too large a load at too high a speed, the motor may stall, or may miss steps and not move the full distance.
The following table shows the velocity settings and the approximate speed they correspond to.
The velocity is fixed for the duration of a move. If you change the velocity while the motor is moving, the change will apply to the next move.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.Motor.IsHomed
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the motor has been homed.

remarks.para: When the device is first opened, the IsHomed property will be false. It will be set true after a homing operation completes successfully.
When you call the Home method, IsHomed is set false until the homing operation completes successfully. If the Home method fails, IsHomed will remain false.

If the device is disconnected, IsHomed will be set false. This occurs when the device is physically disconnected, or if you call the
method.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.Table.LoadSettingsFromRegistry(System.String)
member.summary: Loads properties from a registry key.

remarks.para: This method allows easy configuration of the object, and provides consistent operation across applications.
The method calls the LoadSettingsFromRegistry method for each of the LabJack legs. It also loads the LegLocationX and LegLocationY properties for each leg.
You must connect to the device before calling this method. If you Disconnect and re-Connect to the device, you should call this method again.
The property is not affected by this method, since you must connect to the device before loading the settings.

member.param: The registry keyName to be used. This is not a full path to the key, but is relative to HKCU\Software\Picard Industries\ The standard keyName used by the USB 4D-Labjack software is "USB 4D-LabJack\LegN", where N is 1, 2, and 3.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.Table.SaveSettingsToRegistry(System.String)
member.summary: Saves properties to a registry key.

remarks.para: This method allows easy configuration of the object, and provides consistent operation across applications.
The method calls the SaveSettingsFromRegistry method for each of the LabJack legs. It also saves the LegLocationX and LegLocationY properties for each leg.
You must connect to the device before calling this method.
The property is not saved by this method, since you must connect to the device before loading or saving the settings.

member.param: The registry keyName to be used. This is not a full path to the key, but is relative to HKCU\Software\Picard Industries\ The standard keyName used by the USB 4D-Labjack software is "USB 4D-LabJack\LegN", where N is 1, 2, and 3.

member.name: T:PiUsbNet.Twister
member.summary: Provides an interface to a Twister device.

remarks.para: The USB Twister uses a stepper motor to rotate a shaft.

The twister position is specified in motor steps. There are 200 steps for each revolution of the shaft, so each step corresponds to 1.8 degrees. You can specify any position between -32767 and +32767. If you specify a position less than -32767, the twister will move to position -32767. If you specify a position greater than +32767, the twister will move to position +32767.

You can command the twister to move continuously in either the + or direction with the RunContinuous method. When you call this method, the position is set to zero and remains there during the continuous move. You can leave the twister running for as long as you wish.
The positive direction (increasing counts) is counter-clockwise rotation if you are looking at the USB Twister from the shaft end.
Some versions of the Twister include an integrated absolute position sensor. This is used in the device to provide motion limits and a home position.
The sensor is a rotary potentiometer which is read by an A/D converter. It reports the position of the twister motor shaft as a 10-bit value (0 to 1023) in A/D "counts".

The sensor resolution is not as fine as motor steps, but it provides an absolute position rather than relative to the power-on or user set zero position. This absolute position can be used to establish a home or zero position, and provide motion limits.

remarks.para: If the device is connected when the Close method is called, it will disconnect the device and raise the Disconnected event.
Close does not stop an ongoing move operation. The move will continue to its destination.

member.returns: True if a device was connected.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.Twister.Connect
member.summary: Attempts to connect to the Twister device
member.returns: True if the device is successfully connected.

remarks.para: You must lock the device before calling this method.
If this method succeeds and returns true, you should raise the Connected event.
If a device is already connected, will throw an exception.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.Twister.Velocity
member.summary: Gets or sets the velocity.

remarks.para: The velocity is an integer between 1 and 13, where 1 is the slowest speed and 13 is the fastest speed.

We recommend that you limit your velocity to be 10 or less. These velocities should work well with most devices you connect to the Twister. If your load is small and light, you may be able to use faster velocities (between 11 and 13). If you attempt to move too large a load at too high a speed, the motor may stall, or may miss steps and not move the full distance.
The following table shows the velocity settings and the approximate speed they correspond to.
The velocity is fixed for the duration of a move. If you change the velocity while the twister is moving, the change will apply to the next move.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.Twister.GetPositionAndStatus(System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Gets the position and status of the Twister.

remarks.para:
This method gets the current twister position and status in a single method call. It returns the value of the , , and
properties.
If no sensor is present in the Twister, the SensorPosition will be reported as zero.
It is more efficient to call this method rather than calling the properties individually. Using this method reduces I/O traffic to the device and can improve the responsiveness of your application.

member.param: The current position.
The current value from the sensor.
A value that indicates whether the Twister is moving.

member.name: T:PiUsbNet.ZRotary
member.summary: Provides an interface to a ZRotary device.

remarks.para:
ZRotary is a composite class. It uses a device to move a rotary stage, but provides additional functionality:
You can convert motor steps to other units, typically degrees.
The multi-step Home procedure is handled automatically.

The ZRotary device uses a device with an integrated absolute position sensor. The sensor is a rotary potentiometer which is read by an A/D converter. It reports the position of the twister motor shaft as a 10-bit value (0 to 1023) in A/D "counts". We convert this to degrees using the property.

The sensor does not have as much resolution as motor steps, but it provides an absolute position rather than relative to the power-on or user set zero position. This absolute position can be used to establish a home or zero position, and provide motion limits.
During operation the system will use the sensor position to enforce motion limits.
For proper operation you must set the lower and upper limit locations using either the LoadSettingsFromRegistry method or the and properties.
During the home procedure the system will use the sensor position to establish the home position.
For proper operation, you must set the home location using either the LoadSettingsFromRegistry method or the property.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.MotorStepSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance, in degrees, that the motor shaft is moved for a single step of the motor.
member.remarks: The default value is 0. 04488 degrees. Do not change this value unless you are using non-standard hardware.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.SensorCountSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance, in degrees, that the motor shaft is moved for a single count of the sensor.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.MinSteps
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum step number that the motor can safely move to.
member.remarks: The default value is -32767. Do not change this value unless you are using non-standard hardware.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.MaxSteps
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum step number that the motor can safely move to.
member.remarks: The default value is +32767. Do not change this value unless you are using non-standard hardware.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.SensorLowerLimitCounts
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum sensor position, in counts, that the motor can safely move to.
member.remarks: The default value is 150.

member.name: P:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.SensorUpperLimitCounts

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.Home
member.summary: Initiates the home procedure on the ZRotary.

remarks.para: The ZRotary uses a multi-step home procedure to ensure a reliable home position.
Call this method to initiate the home procedure. Homing is initiated and the method returns without waiting for homing to complete.
You can check whether the device has finished homing with the property or the GetStatus or GetStatusAll methods.

member.name: M:PiUsbNet.ZRotary.LoadSettingsFromRegistry(System.String)
member.summary: Loads properties from a registry key.

remarks.para: This method allows easy configuration of the object, and provides consistent operation across applications.
You must connect to the device before calling this method. If you Disconnect and re-Connect to the device, you should call this method again.
The properties set by this method are:
The property is not affected by this method, since you must connect to the device before loading the settings.

member.param: The registry keyName to be used. This is not a full path to the key, but is relative to HKCU\Software\Picard Industries\ The standard keyName used by the USB 4D-Labjack software is USB 4D-LabJack\ZRotary.

member.param: The registry keyName to be used. This is not a full path to the key, but is relative to HKCU\Software\Picard Industries\ The standard keyName used by the USB 4D-Labjack software is USB 4D-LabJack\ZRotary.
